questions.text: The following image indicating structure of:
questions.solution:
• Hemoglobin S In HbS, the nonpolar amino acid valine has replaced the polar surface residue Glu6 of the β subunit, generating a hydrophobic 'sticky patch' on the surface of the β subunit of both oxyHbS and deoxyHbS.
  • Both HbA and HbS contain a complementary sticky patch on their surfaces that is exposed only in the deoxygenated T state. Thus, at low PO2, deoxyHbS can polymerize to form long, insoluble fibers.
  • Binding of deoxy HbA terminates fiber polymerization, since HbA lacks the second sticky patch necessary to bind another Hb molecule (as shown in below figure). These twisted helical fibers distort the erythrocyte into a characteristic sickle shape, rendering it vulnerable to lysis in the interstices of the splenic sinusoids.

So Option B is correct option.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 6 PN 54

questions.text: Which of the following protein is absent in beta thalassemia?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Thalassemias are caused by genetic defects that impair the synthesis of one of the polypeptide subunits of hemoglobin. During the burst of hemoglobin synthesis that occurs during erythrocyte development, a specific chaperone called α-hemoglobin-stabilizing protein (AHSP) binds to free hemoglobin α-subunits awaiting incorporation into the hemoglobin multimer. In the absence of this chaperone, free α-hemoglobin subunits aggregate, and the resulting precipitate has cytotoxic effects on the developing erythrocyte. Investigations using genetically modified mice suggest a role for AHSP in modulating the severity of β-thalassemia in human subjects.
  • Option B: Alzheimer disease occurs due to defective function of tau protein.

It results in characteristic senile plaques and neurofibrillary bundles contain aggregates of the protein β-amyloid, a 4.3-kDa polypeptide produced by proteolytic cleavage of a larger protein known as amyloid precursor protein. In Alzheimer disease patients, levels of β-amyloid become elevated, and this protein undergoes a conformational transformation from a soluble α helix-rich state to a state rich in β sheet and prone to self aggregation. Apolipoprotein E has been implicated as a potential mediator of this conformational transformation.

  • Option C: Chaperone proteins participate in the folding of over half of all mammalian proteins. The hsp70 (70-kDa heat shock protein) family of chaperones binds short sequences of hydrophobic amino acids that emerge while a new polypeptide is being synthesized, shielding them from solvent. Chaperones prevent aggregation, thus providing an opportunity for the formation of appropriate secondary structural elements and their subsequent coalescence into a molten globule. The hsp60 family of chaperones, sometimes called chaperonins, differs in sequence and structure from hsp70 and its homologs. Hsp60 acts later in the folding process, often together with an hsp70 chaperone. The central cavity of the donut-shaped hsp60 chaperone provides a sheltered nonpolar environment in which a polypeptide can fold until all hydrophobic regions are buried in its interior, thus preempting any tendency toward aggregation.
  • Option D: The transmissible spongiform encephalopathies, or prion diseases, are fatal neurodegenerative diseases characterized by spongiform changes, astrocytic gliomas, and neuronal loss resulting from the deposition of insoluble protein aggregates in neural cells. They include Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease in humans, scrapie in sheep, and bovine spongiform encephalopathy (mad cow disease) in cattle. A variant form of Creutzfeldt-Jacob disease (vCJD) that afflicts younger patients is associated with early-onset psychiatric and behavioral disorders. Prion diseases may manifest themselves as infectious, genetic, or sporadic disorders. Because no viral or bacterial gene encoding the pathologic prion protein could be identified, the source and mechanism of transmission of prion disease long remained elusive. Today it is recognized that prion diseases are protein conformation diseases transmitted by altering the conformation, and hence the physical properties, of proteins endogenous to the host. Human prion-related protein (PrP), a glycoprotein encoded on the short arm of chromosome 20, normally is monomeric and rich in α helix. Pathologic prion proteins serve as the templates for the conformational transformation of normal PrP, known as PrPc, into PrPsc. PrPsc is rich in β sheet with many hydrophobic aminoacyl side chains exposed to solvent. As each new PrPsc molecule is formed, it triggers the production of yet more pathologic variants in a conformational chain reaction. Because PrPsc molecules associate strongly with one another through their exposed hydrophobic regions, the accumulating PrPsc units coalesce to form insoluble protease-resistant aggregates. Since one pathologic prion or prion-related protein can serve as template for the conformational transformation of many times its number of PrPc molecules, prion diseases can be transmitted by the protein alone without involvement of DNA or RNA.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 5 PN 42

questions.text: Different polypeptide chain is held together by:
questions.solution:
• Option A: Peptide bond is seen between two amino acid during formation of protein chain.
  • Option B: Glycosidic bond is formed between two mono saccharides during formation of polysaccharides.
  • Option C: Disulfide bond is formed between two cysteine residues which are present within chain or between two polypeptide chain.
  • Option D: Ester bond is formed between alcohol and fatty acid in lipid formation.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 5 PN 48

questions.text: Sanger's reagent is:
questions.solution:
• SANGER WAS THE FIRST TO DETERMINE THE SEQUENCE OF A POLYPEPTIDE
  • Mature insulin consists of the 21-residue A chain and the 30-residue B chain linked by disulfide bonds.
  • Frederick Sanger reduced the disulfide bonds, separated the A and B chains, and cleaved each chain into smaller peptides using trypsin, chymotrypsin, and pepsin. The resulting peptides were then isolated and hydrolyzed into a mixture of smaller peptides by treatment with acid.
  • Each peptide in the mixture was isolated and treated with 1-fluoro-2,4-dinitrobenzene (Sanger reagent), which reacts with the exposed α-amino groups of the amino-terminal residues. The amino acid content of each peptide was then determined and the amino terminal amino acid was identified.
  • The ε-amino group of lysine also reacts with Sanger reagent; but since an aminoterminal lysine reacts with 2 mol of Sanger reagent, it is readily distinguished from a lysine from the interior of a peptide. Working from di- and tripeptides up through progressively larger fragments, Sanger was able to reconstruct the complete sequence of insulin, an accomplishment for which he received a Nobel Prize in 1958.
  • Sanger, who received his second Nobel prize for his development of techniques for DNA sequencing, died in 2013 at the age of 95.

So, Option C is correct option.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 4 PN 27

choices.text: Distance between two atom is 1.28 A°

questions.text: Which of the following is characteristics of the bond given in below image?
questions.solution:
• The bond shown in above image is peptide bond

Alpha carboxyl group of one amino acid reacts with alpha amino group of other amino acid to form a CO-NH linkage, which known as peptide bond.

Characteristics of a peptide bond

  • Partial double bond because distance is 1.32 A° which is midway between single bond (1.42A°) and a double bond (1.27A°).
  • Trans in nature
  • Rigid, No freedom of rotation because of partial double bond character
  • But side chains are free to rotate on either side of the peptide bond. The angles of rotation is k/a Ramchandran angles. It determine the spatial orientation of peptide chain.

Option A: Peptide bond is trans in nature.

Option B: Peptide bond is partial double bond.

Option C: Peptide bond is rigid bond between C and N.

Option D: Distance between two atom is 1.32 A°.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 3 PN 21

questions.text: Which of the following is a hydrophobic amino acid?
questions.solution:
• Option A, Option B, Option C: Aspartic acid, Asparagine, arginine are hydrophilic amino acids.
  • Option D: Alanine is a hydrophobic amino acid.
  • The R groups of amino acids can be characterized as being either hydrophilic or hydrophobic; properties that affect their location in a protein's mature folded conformation.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 3 PN 17

questions.text: A 35 year old non alcoholics has liver failure. On biopsy, liver contain accumulation of tyrosine. A genetic diagnosis of tyrosinosis was made. Which of the following enzyme is defective in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Several metabolic disorders are associated with the tyrosine catabolic pathway.
  • Option A: Neonatal tyrosinemia occurs due to lowered activity of p-hydroxyphenylpyruvate hydroxylase. Therapy employs a diet low in protein.
  • Option B: Type II tyrosinemia (Richner-Hanhart syndrome) occurs due to defect in tyrosine aminotransferase. Alternate metabolites of tyrosine are also excreted in this defect.
  • Option C: The probable metabolic defect in type I tyrosinemia (tyrosinosis) is at fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase. Therapy employs a diet low in tyrosine and phenylalanine. Untreated acute and chronic tyrosinosis leads to death from liver failure.
  • Option D: Albinism occurs due to deficiency of tyrosinase.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 29 PN 286

choices.text: It results from a defect in Glycine cleavage system
Occurs due to defect in renal tubular reabsorption
Results in oxalate stone in urine

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Glycinuria?
questions.solution:
• Option A & Option C: The glycine cleavage complex of liver mitochondria splits glycine to CO2 and NH4+ and forms N5, N10-methylene tetrahydrofolate.
  • Glycine + H4 folate + NAD+ → CO2 + NH3 + 5,10-CH2 -H4 folate + NADH + H+
  • The glycine cleavage system consists of three enzymes and an 'H-protein' that has a covalently attached dihydrolipoyl moiety.
  • A rare inborn error of glycine degradation (due to defect in glycine cleavage system), glycine accumulates in all body tissues including the central nervous system. Also leads to nonketotic hyperglycinemia.
  • Option D: The defect in primary hyperoxaluria is the failure to catabolize glyoxylate formed by the deamination of glycine. Subsequent oxidation of glyoxylate to oxalate results in urolithiasis, nephrocalcinosis, and early mortality from renal failure or hypertension.
  • Option B: Glycinuria is a benign disorders which results from a defect in renal tubular reabsorption.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 29 PN 283

choices.text: Associated impairment of hydroxyproline catabolism also
Defective enzyme involved in catabolism of arginine also
Δ1 -pyrroline-5-carboxylate is excreted in urine of this patient

questions.text: A 30 year old male accidently diagnosed to have metabolic defect of proline catabolism. He does not have any clinical feature except high blood level of proline. A diagnosis of type I hyperprolinemia was made. Which of the following is true regarding this metabolic defect?
questions.solution:
Catabolism of proline:

  • Since proline does not participate in transamination, its α-amino nitrogen is retained throughout a two-stage oxidation to glutamate. Oxidation to Δ1 -pyrroline-5-carboxylate is catalyzed by proline dehydrogenase. Subsequent oxidation to glutamate is catalyzed by Δ1 -pyrroline-5-carboxylate dehydrogenase (also called glutamate-γ-semialdehyde dehydrogenase.
  • There are two metabolic disorders of proline catabolism. Inherited as autosomal recessive traits, both are consistent with a normal adult life.

  • Option A: The metabolic block in type I hyperprolinemia is at proline dehydrogenase. There is no associated impairment of hydroxyproline catabolism.
  • Option B: The catabolism of proline takes place in mitochondria. All enzymes present in mitochondria.
  • Option C & Option D: The metabolic block in type II hyperprolinemia is at Δ1 -pyrroline-5-carboxylate dehydrogenase, which also participates in the catabolism of arginine, ornithine, and hydroxyproline. Since proline and hydroxyproline catabolism are affected, both Δ1 -pyrroline-5-carboxylate and Δ1 -pyrroline 3-hydroxy-5-carboxylate are excreted.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 29 PN 282

questions.text: Which of the following is purely glucogenic amino acid?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Leucine and lysine are purely ketogenic amino acids.
  • Option B & Option D: Isoleucine, phenyl alanine, tyrosine and tryptophane are both ketogenic and glucogenic amino acids.
  • Option C: Rest are purely glucogenic amino acids.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 29 PN 281

questions.text: A child having mutation of the ORNT1 gene that encodes the mitochondrial membrane ornithine permease protein. It is characterised by following features, except:
questions.solution:
• Option A, Option B, Option D:The hyperornithinemia, hyperammonemia, and homocitrullinuria (HHH) syndrome results from mutation of the ORNT1 gene that encodes the mitochondrial membrane ornithine permease.
  • The failure to import cytosolic ornithine into the mitochondrial matrix renders the urea cycle inoperable, with consequent hyperammonemia, and hyperornithinemia due to the accompanying accumulation of cytosolic ornithine.
  • In the absence of its normal acceptor (ornithine), mitochondrial carbamoyl phosphate carbamoylates lysine to homocitrulline, resulting in homocitrullinuria.
  • Option C: Hyperhomocysteinemia is not associated with urea cycle. It occurs due to many causes which may be genetic or nutritional (deficiency of vitamin B12, folic acid, vitamin B6).

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 28 PN 277

questions.text: Which one of the following is a pacemaker enzyme of urea cycle?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Arginase breakdown arginine into urea and ornithine in last step.
  • Option B: Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I initiate urea biosynthesis.
  • Condensation of CO2 , ammonia, and ATP to form carbamoyl phosphate is catalyzed by mitochondrial carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I.
  • The activity of carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I is determined by N-acetylglutamate, whose steady-state level is dictated by the balance between its rate of synthesis from acetyl-CoA and glutamate and its rate of hydrolysis to acetate and glutamate, reactions catalyzed by N-acetylglutamate synthetase (NAGS) and N-acetylglutamate deacylase (hydrolase), respectively
  • Major changes in diet can increase the concentrations of individual urea cycle enzymes 10- to 20-fold. For example, starvation elevates enzyme levels, presumably to cope with the increased production of ammonia that accompanies enhanced starvation-induced degradation of protein.
  • Option C: A cytosolic form of this enzyme, carbamoyl phosphate synthetase II, uses glutamine rather than ammonia as the nitrogen donor and functions in pyrimidine biosynthesis.
  • Option D: l-Ornithine transcarbamoylase catalyzes transfer of the carbamoyl group of carbamoyl phosphate to ornithine, forming citrulline and orthophosphate.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 28 PN 276

choices.text: ε-amino groups of lysyl residues of hemoglobin β chains
α-amino group of lysyl residues of hemoglobin β chains
ε-amino groups of lysyl residues of hemoglobin α chains
α-amino group of lysyl residues of hemoglobin α chains

questions.text: A 64 year old male having type 2 diabetes mellitus since 8 years. During routine visit to endocrinologist, his FBS and PP2BS was found very high. Such glucose when enter into erythrocytes and can bind with:
questions.solution:
• GLYCATED HEMOGLOBIN (HbA1c)
  • Blood glucose that enters the erythrocytes can form a covalent adduct with the ε-amino groups of lysyl residues and the N-terminal valines of hemoglobin β chains, a process referred to as glycation.
  • Unlike glycosylation, glycation is not enzyme catalyzed. The fraction of hemoglobin glycated, normally about 5%, is proportionate to blood glucose concentration.
  • Since the half-life of an erythrocyte is typically 60 days, the level of glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) reflects the mean blood glucose concentration over the preceding 6 to 8 weeks. Measurement of HbA1c therefore provides valuable information for management of diabetes mellitus.
  • So Option A is correct option.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 6 PN 55

questions.text: Name the enzyme which catalyzed the following reaction.
questions.solution:
• Option A: Glutamate transaminase help in transamination rection, that is transfer of amino group between amino acid and ketoacid.
  • Option B: Glutamine synthase involve in conversion of glutamate to glutamine.

  • Option C: Transfer of amino nitrogen to α-ketoglutarate forms l-glutamate occurs by Hepatic l-glutamate dehydrogenase (GDH), which can use either NAD+ or NADP+, releases this nitrogen as ammonia.

  • Option D: Hydrolytic release of the amide nitrogen of glutamine as ammonia, catalyzed by glutaminase.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 28 PN 274

questions.text: Which of the following participate in transamination rection?
questions.solution:
• Transamination transfers α-amino nitrogen to α-ketoglutarate and forming glutamate. Transamination reactions interconvert pairs of α-amino acids and α-keto acids. Transamination reactions, which are freely reversible, also function in amino ac biosynthesis.
  • All of the common amino acids except lysine, threonine, proline, and hydroxyproline participate in transamination. Transamination is not restricted to α-amino groups. The δ-amino group of ornithine (but not the ε-amino group of lysine) readily undergoes transamination.
  • Option A: The δ-amino group of ornithine will participate in transamination reactions.
  • Option B, Option C & Option D: All of the common amino acids except lysine, threonine, proline, and hydroxyproline participate in transamination.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 28 PN 273

questions.text: All of the following metalloprotein contain Zinc, except:
questions.solution:
• Option A: Aconitase contain Fe - S center, not zinc.
  • Option B, Option C & Option D: Alkaline phosphatase, Alcohol dehydrogenase & Matrix metalloprotease contain zinc.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 10 PN 97

questions.text: All of the following are mechanisms for toxicity by heavy metals, except:
questions.solution:
• Toxicity of heavy metals

Most heavy metals, a loosely defined term for metallic elements with densities greater than 5 g/cm3 or atomic numbers > 20, are toxic. Some well-known examples include arsenic, antimony, lead, mercury, and cadmium, whose toxicity can arise via a number of mechanisms like Displacement of an Essential Cation, Enzyme Inactivation and Formation of Reactive Oxygen Species.

  • Option A: Displacement of an Essential Cation:

The ability of a heavy metal to displace a functionally essential metal can readily lead to loss or impairment of function. Classic examples include the displacement of iron by gallium in the enzymes ribonucleotide reductase and Fe, Cu superoxide dismutase. Ga3+, while of similar size and identical charge to Fe3+, lacks the multivalence capability of iron. Replacement of Fe3+ by Ga3+ therefore renders affected enzymes catalytically inert.

  • Option B: Heavy metals are not displacing anions.
  • Option C: Enzyme Inactivation: Heavy metals readily form adducts with free sulfhydryl groups. If present in proteins, formation of these adducts undermines a protein's structural integrity, with concomitant impairment of function. Examples include the inhibition of δ-aminolevulinate synthase by Pb and the inactivation of the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex by arsenic or mercury. In pyruvate dehydrogenase, the heavy metals react with the sulfhydryl on the essential prosthetic group, lipoic acid, rather than with a peptidyl cysteine.
  • Option D: Formation of Reactive Oxygen Species: Heavy metals can induce the formation of reactive oxygen species (ROS), which can then damage DNA, membrane lipids, and other biomolecules. Oxidative damage to DNA can cause genetic mutations that may lead to cancer or other pathophysiologic conditions. ROS-mediated peroxidation of lipid molecules can lead to the loss of membrane integrity. The resulting dissipation of action potentials and disruption of various cross-membrane transport processes can be particularly deleterious to neurologic and neuromuscular functions. It has also been reported that rats fed with excessive levels of heavy metals are prone to develop cancerous tumors.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 10 PN 93

questions.text: Coenzymes are:
questions.solution:
• Option A: A non-protein part of enzyme is termed as Coenzyme.
  • Coenzyme is a low molecular weight organic substance. It is heat stable
  • In general, the protein part of the enzyme gives the necessary three dimensional infrastructure for chemical reaction; but the group is transferred from or accepted by the co-enzyme. It is essential for the biological activity of the enzyme.
  • Option B: Almost all enzyme are protein in nature except ribozymes which is RNA in nature

They follow physical & chemical reactions of protein like

  • Heat labile
  • Water-soluble
  • Can be precipitated by protein precipitating reagents like ammonium sulfate or trichloro acetic acid
  • Contain 16% weight as nitrogen
  • Subject to denaturation at high or low pH
  • Option C: Different form of same enzyme are known as Isoenzyme
  • Option D: Structural analogues of enzyme may act as inhibitor of enzyme.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 7 PN 58

questions.text: Enzymes that involved in cleavage of covalent bond by atom elimination are termed as:
questions.solution:
• International Union of Biochemistry (IUB) developed a system of enzyme nomenclature in which each enzyme has a unique name and code number that identify the type of reaction catalyzed. Enzymes are grouped into six classes.
  • Option A: Hydrolases-enzymes that catalyze hydrolytic cleavage of C-C, C-O, C-N, and other covalent bonds.
  • Option B: Lyases-enzymes that catalyze cleavage of C-C, C-O, C-N, and other covalent bonds by atom elimination, generating double bonds.
  • Option C: Isomerases-enzymes that catalyze geometric or structural changes within a molecule.
  • Option D: Oxidoreductases-enzymes that catalyze oxidations and reductions.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 7 PN 57

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme act by mechanisms of covalent catalysis?
questions.solution:
Option A, Option C, Option D:

  • Enzymes of the aspartic protease family, which includes the digestive enzyme pepsin, the lysosomal cathepsins, and the protease produced by the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), share a common mechanism that employs two conserved aspartyl residues as acid-base catalysts.
  • In the first stage of the reaction, one aspartate functions as a general base (Asp X) that extracts a proton from a water molecule to make it more nucleophilic. The resulting nucleophile then attacks the electrophilic carbonyl carbon of the peptide bond targeted for hydrolysis, forming a tetrahedral transition state intermediate.
  • A second aspartate (Asp Y) then facilitates the decomposition of this tetrahedral intermediate by donating a proton to the amino group produced by rupture of the peptide bond.
  • The two active site aspartates can act simultaneously as a general base or as a general acid because their immediate environment favors ionization of one, but not the other.
  • Option B: Chymotrypsin & fructose 2, 6-bisphosphatase illustrate covalent catalysis
  • Chymotrypsin While catalysis by aspartic proteases involves the direct hydrolytic attack of water on a peptide bond, catalysis by the serine protease chymotrypsin involves formation of a covalent acyl-enzyme intermediate.
  • A conserved seryl residue, serine 195, is activated via interactions with histidine 57 and aspartate 102. While these three residues are far apart in primary structure, in the active site of the mature, folded protein they reside within bond-forming distance of one another. Aligned in the order Asp 102-His 57-Ser 195, this trio forms a linked charge-relay network that acts as a 'proton shuttle.'
  • Binding of substrate initiates proton shifts that in effect transfer the hydroxyl proton of Ser 195 to Asp 102. The enhanced nucleophilicity of the seryl oxygen facilitates its attack on the carbonyl carbon of the peptide bond of the substrate, forming a covalent acyl-enzyme intermediate.
  • The proton on Asp 102 then shuttles via His 57 to the amino group liberated when the peptide bond is cleaved. The portion of the original peptide with a free amino group then leaves the active site and is replaced by a water molecule. The charge-relay network now activates the water molecule by withdrawing a proton through His 57 to Asp 102
  • . The resulting hydroxide ion attacks the acyl-enzyme intermediate, and a reverse proton shuttle returns a proton to Ser 195, restoring its original state. While modified during the process of catalysis, chymotrypsin emerges unchanged on completion of the reaction.
  • The proteases trypsin and elastase employ a similar catalytic mechanism, but the numbering of the residues in their Ser-His-Asp proton shuttles differ.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 7 PN 60

questions.text: During hepatolenticular degeneration, which of the enzyme level is increased in blood?
questions.solution:
• Option A & Option B: Amylase & lipase level increased during pancreatitis.
  • Option C: Creatine kinase level increased during muscle disorders.
  • Option D: A level of ceruloplasmin is increased during hepatolenticular degeneration. A ceruloplasmin is plasma protein which bind with copper and help in transport of copper. It also having enzymatic activity.
  • Hepatolenticular degeneration occurs due to copper accumulation, termed as Wilson’s disease.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 7 PN 64

questions.text: Which of the following best describe the behaviour of enzyme that exhibit cooperative binding of substrate?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Most enzymes that display the simple saturation kinetics are adequately described by the Michaelis-Menten expression.
  • Option B: The Hill equation describe the behaviour of enzyme that exhibit cooperative binding of substrate.
  • Option C & Option D: Ficher’s template theory and Koshland’s induced fit theory describe binding of substrate to enzyme.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 8 PN 76

choices.text: Lineweaver-Burk plot of simple competitive inhibition
Lineweaver-Burk plot of simple non competitive inhibition
Graphical representation of a linear form of the Hill equation
Representation of sigmoid substrate saturation kinetics

questions.text: Identify the following graph:
questions.solution:
• Option A: Lineweaver-Burk plot of simple competitive inhibition is indicated by following graph

  • Option B: Lineweaver-Burk plot of simple non competitive inhibition

  • Option C: A graphical representation of a linear form of the Hill equation is used to evaluate S50, the substrate concentration that produces half-maximal velocity, and the degree of cooperativity n.

  • Option D: Representation of sigmoid substrate saturation kinetics is shown as S shape curve

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 8 PN 77

questions.text: Name the molecule indicated (by ?) in below image:
questions.solution:
• Option A: Triglyceride is produced during lipogenesis by attachment of fatty acid and glycerol in well fed state. It will not enter into TCA cycle.
  • Option B: Glycogen is also synthesized by glycogenesis from glucose in well fed state. It will not enter into TCA cycle.
  • Option C: Acyl CoA is long chain fatty acid produced from 2 carbon acetyl CoA by fatty acid synthesis in well fed state.
  • Option D: Carbohydrate (mainly glucose), protein and fat when catabolized, leads to the production of acetyl-CoA, which is oxidized in the citric acid cycle, ultimately yielding ATP by the process of oxidative phosphorylation. So TCA cycle is considered as final common metabolic hub.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 14 PN 130

questions.text: The carbon skeletons for the synthesis of dispensable amino acids are provided by:
questions.solution:
• Option A: HMP shunt or pentose phosphate pathway, an alternative to part of the pathway of glycolysis. It is a source of reducing equivalents (NADPH) for fatty acid synthesis and the source of ribose for nucleotide and nucleic acid synthesis.
  • Option B: Gluconeogenesis is the process of synthesizing glucose from noncarbohydrate precursors such as lactate, amino acids, and glycerol.
  • Option C: Triose phosphate intermediates in glycolysis give rise to the glycerol moiety of triacylglycerols.
  • Option D: Pyruvate and intermediates of the citric acid cycle provide the carbon skeletons for the synthesis of nonessential or dispensable amino acids.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 14 PN 130

questions.text: All of the following metabolic pathways take place in cytoplasm, except:
questions.solution:
• Option A: Mitochondria contains the enzymes of the citric acid cycle, β-oxidation of fatty acids and ketogenesis, as well as the respiratory chain and ATP synthase.
  • Option B, Option C, Option D: Glycolysis, the pentose phosphate pathway, and fatty acid synthesis all occur in the cytosol.
  • Compartmentation of pathways in separate subcellular compartments or organelles permits integration and regulation of metabolism.
  • The central role of the mitochondrion is immediately apparent, since it acts as the focus of carbohydrate, lipid, and amino acid metabolism. It contains the enzymes of the citric acid cycle, β-oxidation of fatty acids and ketogenesis, as well as the respiratory chain and ATP synthase.
  • Glycolysis, the pentose phosphate pathway, and fatty acid synthesis all occur in the cytosol.
  • In gluconeogenesis, substrates such as lactate and pyruvate, which are formed in the cytosol, enter the mitochondrion to yield oxaloacetate as a precursor for the synthesis of glucose in the cytosol.
  • The membranes of the endoplasmic reticulum contain the enzyme system for triacylglycerol synthesis, and the ribosomes are responsible for protein synthesis.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 14 PN 134

questions.text: Which of the following hormone or metabolic fuel level in blood is decreased during the onset of starvation?
questions.solution:
• Option A: The level of insulin is decreased during onset of starvation. The level of insulin is increased in fed state.
  • Option B, Option C, Option D: The level of glucagon, fatty acid & ketone body are increased during onset of starvation.
  • Relative changes in plasma hormones and metabolic fuels during the onset of starvation

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 14 PN 139

questions.text: The end product of glycolysis in fast twitch muscle is:
questions.solution:
• Option A: Acetyl CoA is produced from pyruvate in aerobic condition by PDH reaction.
  • Option B: Glycolysis is breakdown of glucose. So glucose is used for glycolysis as substrate, not product.
  • Option C: Pyruvate is end product of aerobic glycolysis.
  • Option D: A fast twitch muscle undergoes anaerobic glycolysis, so produces lactate as end product.

So option D is correct option.


Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 14 PN 139

questions.text: Glucose and fructose are:
questions.solution:
• Option A: Isomers differing as a result of variations in configuration of the —OH and —H on carbon atoms 2, 3, and 4 of glucose are known as epimers. Biologically, the most important epimers of glucose are mannose (epimerized at carbon 2) and galactose (epimerized at carbon 4).
  • Option D: Galactose and mannose are not epimers but termed as diastereoisomers.
  • Option B: Alpha- and beta-anomers: The ring structure of an aldose is a hemiacetal, since it is formed by reaction between an aldehyde and an alcohol group. Similarly, the ring structure of a ketose is a hemiketal. Crystalline glucose is α-d-glucopyranose. The cyclic structure is retained in the solution, but isomerism occurs about position 1, the carbonyl or anomeric carbon atom, to give a mixture of α-glucopyranose (38%) and β-glucopyranose (62%). Less than 0.3% is represented by α- and β-anomers of glucofuranose.
  • Option C: Aldose-ketose isomerism: Fructose has the same molecular formula as glucose but differs in that there is a potential keto group in position 2, the anomeric carbon of fructose, whereas in glucose there is a potential aldehyde group in position 1, the anomeric carbon.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 15 PN 143

questions.text: Which of the following form of glucose is present in major amount in solution?
questions.solution:
• Alpha- and beta-anomers: The ring structure of an aldose is a hemiacetal, since it is formed by reaction between an aldehyde and an alcohol group. Similarly, the ring structure of a ketose is a hemiketal.
  • Crystalline glucose is α-d-glucopyranose.
  • The cyclic structure is retained in the solution, but isomerism occurs about position 1, the carbonyl or anomeric carbon atom, to give a mixture of α-glucopyranose (38%) and β-glucopyranose (62%). Less than 0.3% is represented by α- and β-anomers of glucofuranose.

So Option B is correct option.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 15 PN 143

choices.text: 0 for those which are readily hydrolysed in intestine
1 for those that are not hydrolysed at all
Based on extent to which it reduces blood glucose level compared to equivalent amount of glucose

questions.text: Glycemic index of starch food is:
questions.solution:
• Option A: The glycemic index of a starchy food is a measure of its digestibility.
  • Option B & Option C: Glycemic index ranges from 1 (or 100%) for starches that are readily hydrolyzed in the small intestine to 0 for those that are not hydrolysed at all.
  • Option D: Glycemic index is based on the extent to which it raises the blood concentration of glucose compared with an equivalent amount of glucose or a reference food such as white bread or boiled rice.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 15 PN 145

questions.text: Inulin is:
questions.solution:
• Option A: Insulin is hormone regulating blood glucose level.
  • Option B: Inulin is a polysaccharide of fructose (a fructosan) found in tubers and roots of dahlias, artichokes, and dandelions.
  • Option C: It is not hydrolyzed by intestinal enzymes, so has no nutritional value.
  • Option D: It is readily soluble in water and is used to determine the glomerular filtration rate.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 15 PN 146

questions.text: The poison fluoroacetate is found in some of the plants, and their consumption can be fatal to animals. It is toxic because it inhibits enzyme:
questions.solution:
• The poison fluoroacetate is found in some of the plants, and their consumption can be fatal to animals. Some fluorinated compounds used as anticancer agents and pesticides are metabolized to fluoroacetate.
  • Option A: Malonic acid inhibits succinate dehydrogenase enzyme.
  • Option B: Cytochrome oxidase is complex IV in ECT and it is inhibited by Cyanide, Azide, Carbon monoxide (CO), H2
  • Option C: Fluoroacetate is toxic because fluoroacetyl-CoA condenses with oxaloacetate to form fluorocitrate, which inhibits aconitase, causing citrate to accumulate.
  • Option D: Cytochrome reductase is complex III in ETC and it is inhibited by Antimycin A, BAL, Naphthoquinone etc.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 16 PN 151

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of substrate level phosphorylation in TCA cycle?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Alpha keto glutarate dehydrogenase enzyme converts alpha keto glutarate into succinyl CoA. It produces NADH2, not produce energy directly, so not an example of substrate level phosphorylation.
  • Option B: Succinate dehydrogenase converts succinate into fumerate. It will produce FADH2, not produce energy directly, so not an example of substrate level phosphorylation.
  • Option C: Succinyl-CoA is converted to succinate by the enzyme succinate thiokinase (succinyl-CoA synthetase). This is the only example of substrate-level phosphorylation in the citric acid cycle
  • Option D: Phosphoglycerate kinase converts 1,3 biphosphoglycerate into 3 phosphoglycerate, and generate ATP. This is an example of substrate level phosphorylation. But this enzyme is involved in glycolysis, not in TCA cycle.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 16 PN 153

questions.text: All of the following vitamin require for α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase reaction, except:
questions.solution:
• Alpha keto glutarate dehydrogenase reaction converts alpha keto glutarate into succinyl CoA in TCA cycle.
  • The α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase complex requires the same cofactors as the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex—thiamin diphosphate, lipoate, Niacin (NAD+), Riboflavin as flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD), and CoA—and results in the formation of succinyl-CoA

It doesn’t require folic acid.

So Option D is correct.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 16 PN 152

questions.text: In which of the following clinical condition, rate of glycolysis is higher than normal?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Heart muscle, which is adapted for aerobic performance, has relatively low glycolytic activity and poor survival under conditions of ischemia.
  • Option B & Option C: Diseases in which enzymes of glycolysis (eg, pyruvate kinase) are deficient are mainly seen as hemolytic anemias or, if the defect affects skeletal muscle (eg, phosphofructokinase), as fatigue.
  • Option D: In fast-growing cancer cells, glycolysis proceeds at a high rate, forming large amounts of pyruvate, which is reduced to lactate and exported. This produces a relatively acidic local environment in the tumor. The lactate is used for gluconeogenesis in the liver, an energy-expensive process, which is responsible for much of the hypermetabolism seen in cancer cachexia.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 17 PN 157

questions.text: When a muscle contracts under anaerobic conditions:
questions.solution:
• When a muscle contracts under anaerobic conditions, glycogen disappears and lactate appears. When oxygen is admitted, aerobic recovery takes place and lactate is no longer produced.
  • If muscle contraction occurs under aerobic conditions, lactate does not accumulate and pyruvate is the end product of glycolysis. Pyruvate is oxidized further to CO2 and water.
  • When oxygen is in short supply, mitochondrial reoxidation of NADH formed during glycolysis is impaired, and NADH is reoxidized by reducing pyruvate to lactate, so permitting glycolysis to continue.
  • While glycolysis can occur under anaerobic conditions, this has a price, for it limits the amount of ATP formed per mole of glucose oxidized, so that much more glucose must be metabolized under anaerobic than aerobic conditions.

So Option A is correct option.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 17 PN 157

questions.text: Following reactions (as indicated in below images) are blocked in:
questions.solution:
• Above both reactions are blocked under anaerobic conditions or by absence of mitochondria containing key respiratory enzymes, as in erythrocytes.

So option C is correct option.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 17 PN 158

questions.text: Methylmalonic aciduria occurs due to deficiency of:
questions.solution:
• Option A: Vitamin B1 deficiency lead to beriberi.
  • Option B: Vitamin B3 deficiency leads to pellagra.
  • Option C: Vitamin B9 deficiency leads to anemia.
  • Option D: Vitamin B12 deficiency leads to methylmalonic aciduria. Vitamin B12 deficiency can also lead to neurological feature like Subacute combined degeneration of spinal cord (SACD).
  • Methylmalonyl-CoA mutase is a vitamin B12-dependent enzyme, and in deficiency, methylmalonic acid is excreted in the urine (methylmalonic aciduria).

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 19 PN 174

questions.text: Muscle cannot contribute to blood glucose level due to absence of enzyme:
questions.solution:
• Option A: Glycogen phosphorylase catalyzes the rate-limiting step in glycogenolysis. It catalyzes the phosphorolytic cleavage of the 1 → 4 linkages of glycogen to yield glucose-1-phosphate.
  • Option B: The conversion of glucose-6-phosphate to glucose is catalyzed by glucose-6-phosphatase. It is present in liver and kidney, but absent from muscle, which, therefore, cannot export glucose into the bloodstream.
  • Option C: The conversion of fructose 1,6-bisphosphate to fructose6-phosphate, for the reversal of glycolysis, is catalyzed by fructose 1,6-bisphosphatase.
  • Its presence determines whether a tissue is capable of synthesizing glucose (or glycogen) not only from pyruvate but also from triose phosphates. It is present in liver, kidney, and skeletal muscle, but is probably absent from heart and smooth muscle.
  • Option D: Glucokinase convers glucose into glucose 6 phosphate during glycolysis.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 19 PN 174

questions.text: Which of the following is an omega 3 fatty acid?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Oleic acid (C18:1;9) is Omega 9 unsaturated fatty acid.
  • Option B: Linoleic acid (C18:2;9,12) is Omega 6 unsaturated fatty acid.
  • Option C: Gamma linolenic acid (C18:3;6,9,12) is Omega 6 unsaturated fatty acid.
  • Option D: Cervonic acid (C22:6;4,7,10,13,16,19) is Omega 3 unsaturated fatty acid.

< p > Reference: Harper & rsquo;s illustrated biochemistry 31 < sup > st < /sup> edition CH 21 PN 197

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme is used in activation of fatty acid?
questions.solution:
• Option A: In final step of beta oxidation, 3-ketoacyl-CoA is split at the 2,3-position by thiolase (3-ketoacyl-CoA-thiolase), forming acetyl-CoA and a new acyl-CoA two carbons shorter than the original acyl-CoA molecule.
  • Option B: Fatty acids must first be converted to an active intermediate before they can be catabolized. This is the only step in the complete degradation of a fatty acid that requires energy from ATP. In the presence of ATP and coenzyme A, the enzyme acyl-CoA synthetase (thiokinase) catalyzes the conversion of a fatty acid (or FFA) to an “active fatty acid” or acyl-CoA, using one high energy phosphate and forming AMP and PPi.
  • Option C: In extrahepatic tissues, during ketolysis, acetoacetate is activated to aceto acetyl-CoA by succinyl-CoA-acetoacetate-CoA transferase. This enzyme also known as thiophorase.
  • Option D: The initial reaction for the carboxylation of acetyl-CoA to malonyl-CoA occurs in the presence of ATP and acetyl-CoA carboxylase. This enzyme has a major role in the regulation of fatty acid synthesis.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 21 PN 208

questions.text: The end product of pyrimidine catabolism is:
questions.solution:
• Option A: Urea is an end product of amino acid catabolism (ammonia detoxification).
  • Option B: Uric acid is an end product of purine catabolism.
  • Option C: The end product of pyrimidine like uracil catabolism will be beta amino isobutyrate or beta alanine & then beta amino isobutyrate is excreted in urine.
  • Option D: Glycine is an amino acid.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 32 PN 325

questions.text: All of the following determine the rate of denovo purine nucleotide biosynthesis, except:
questions.solution:
• Biosynthesis of IMP is energetically expensive. In addition to ATP, glycine, glutamine, aspartate, and reduced tetrahydrofolate derivatives all are consumed. Thus, it is of survival advantage to closely regulate purine biosynthesis in response to varying physiologic need.
  • Option A & Option B:
  • The rate of PRPP synthesis depends on the availability of ribose 5-phosphate and on the activity of PRPP synthetase, an enzyme whose activity is feedback inhibited by AMP, ADP, GMP, and GDP. Elevated levels of these nucleoside phosphates thus signal a physiologically appropriate overall decrease in their biosynthesis.
  • Option C: The overall determinant of the rate of de novo purine nucleotide biosynthesis is the concentration of PRPP. This, in turn, depends on the rate of PRPP synthesis, utilization, degradation, and regulation.
  • Option D: Glycine used in purine denovo biosynthesis, but not determine rate of purine biosynthesis.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 33 PN 330

questions.text: All of the following are source of nitrogen atoms of purine ring during purine biosynthesis, except:
questions.solution:
• Option A, Option C & Option D: Glutamine, Aspartate & Glycine are sources of nitrogen atom of purine ring.
  • Option B: Glutamate is not a sources of nitrogen atom of purine rind during purine biosynthesis.

Sources of the nitrogen and carbon atoms of the purine ring.


Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 33 PN 328

questions.text: Beta hydroxy butyric aciduria is a metabolic disease related to pyrimidine catabolism. It occurs due to low level of enzyme dihydro pyrimidine dehydrogenase. Non genetic form of this disease can be triggered by administration of which of the following drug?
questions.solution:
• β-hydroxybutyric aciduria, a disorder due to total or partial deficiency of the enzyme dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase.
  • A disorder of pyrimidine catabolism, known also as combined uraciluria-thyminuria, is also a disorder of β-amino acid metabolism, since the formation of β-alanine and of β-aminoisobutyrate is impaired.
  • When caused by a genetic error, there are serious neurologic complications. A nongenetic form is triggered by the administration of the anticancer drug 5-fluorouracil to patients with low levels of dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase.

So Option D is correct.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 33 PN 336

choices.text: 5' terminal end has 7 methyl guanosine triphosphate cap
3' terminal end has poly A tail
Pre mRNA is shorter than mature mRNA molecule

questions.text: All of the following is characteristic features of messenger RNA, except:
questions.solution:
• Option A: 5’ terminal end is capped by 7 methyl guanosine triphosphate
  • Option B: 3’ terminal end has poly A tail.
  • Option C: Messenger RNA is the most heterogeneous in abundance, size, and stability.
  • Option D: In mammalian cell nuclei, the immediate products of gene transcription (primary transcripts or pre mRNA) are very heterogeneous and can be greater than 10- to 50-fold longer than mature mRNA molecules. Such pre-mRNA molecules are processed to generate mRNA molecules, which then enter the cytoplasm to serve as templates for protein synthesis.
  • Messenger RNA
  • Messenger RNA is the most heterogeneous in abundance, size, and stability. A specific transcriptional and posttranscriptional mechanisms contribute to this large dynamic range in mRNA content.
  • All members of this RNA class function as messengers conveying the information in a gene to the protein-synthesizing machinery, where each mRNA serves as a template on which a specific sequence of amino acids is polymerized to form a specific protein molecule, the ultimate gene product.
  • Eukaryotic mRNAs have unique chemical characteristics.

The 5′ terminus of mRNA is “capped” by a 7-methylguanosine triphosphate that is linked to an adjacent 2′-O-methyl ribonucleoside at its 5′-hydroxyl through the three phosphates. The cap is involved in the recognition of mRNA by the translation machinery, and also helps stabilize the mRNA by preventing the nucleolytic attack by 5′-exoribonucleases. The protein-synthesizing machinery begins translating the mRNA into proteins beginning downstream of the 5′ or capped terminus.

  • At the other end of almost all eukaryotic mRNA molecules, the 3′-hydroxyl terminus has an attached, nongenetically encoded polymer of adenylate residues 20 to 250 nucleotides in length. The poly(A) “tail” at the 3′-end of mRNAs maintains the intracellular stability of the specific mRNA by preventing the attack of 3′-exoribonucleases and also facilitates translation.
  • Both the mRNA “cap” and “poly(A) tail” are added posttranscriptionally by nontemplate-directed enzymes to mRNA precursor molecules (pre-mRNA).
  • mRNA represents 2 to 5% of total eukaryotic cellular RNA.
  • In mammalian cells, including cells of humans, the mRNA molecules present in the cytoplasm are not the RNA products immediately synthesized from the DNA template but must be formed by processing from the precursor, or pre-mRNA before entering the cytoplasm. Thus, in mammalian cell nuclei, the immediate products of gene transcription (primary transcripts) are very heterogeneous and can be greater than 10- to 50-fold longer than mature mRNA molecules. Such pre-mRNA molecules are processed to generate mRNA molecules, which then enter the cytoplasm to serve as templates for protein synthesis.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 34 PN 344

questions.text: A 60 year old male detected to have nonpolyposis colon cancer during colonoscopy. It was found to be hereditary in nature. Which of the following DNA repair mechanism can be defective here?
questions.solution:
• Repair of damaged DNA is critical for maintaining genomic integrity and thereby preventing the propagation of mutations, either horizontally (somatic cells), or vertically (germ cells). DNA is subjected to a huge array of chemical, physical, and biologic assaults on a daily basis, hence efficient recognition and repair of DNA lesions is essential. Consequently, eukaryotic cells contain five major DNA repair pathways.
  • The mechanisms of DNA repair include
  • Nucleotide excision repair (NER);
  • Mismatch repair (MMR);
  • Base excision repair (BER);
  • Homologous recombination (HR); and n
  • Nonhomologous end-joining (NHEJ) repair pathways

There are many diseases are associated with defective DNA repair mechanism:


So Option B is correct option.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 35 PN 370

choices.text: Made up of short AG rich repeats
Its length is increased in cancer cell

questions.text: The ends of each chromosome are termed as telomeres, which is:
questions.solution:
• Option A: Telomeres consist of short TG-rich repeats. Human telomeres have a variable number of repeats of the sequence 5′-TTAGGG-3′, which can extend for several kilobases.
  • Option C: Telomerase, a multisubunit RNA template-containing complex related to viral RNA-dependent DNA polymerases (reverse transcriptases), is the enzyme responsible for telomere synthesis and thus for maintaining the length of the telomere.
  • Option B & Option D: Telomere shortening has been associated with both malignant transformation and aging, so telomere and telomerase enzyme has become an attractive target for cancer chemotherapy and drug development.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 35 PN 355

questions.text: A 42 year old male presented with photosensitivity in skin clinic. His urine shows increased amount of urinary uroporphyrin I. A diagnosis of porphyria cutanea tarda was made. Which of the following enzyme of heme biosynthesis is found to be defective in liver?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Uroporphyrinogen I synthase leads to acute intermittent porphyria.
  • Option B: Uroporphyrinogen III synthase leads to congenital erythropoietic porphyria.
  • Option C: Uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase deficiency in liver lead to porphyria cutanea tarda.
  • Porphyria Cutanea Tarda (PCT)
  • Most common type of porphyria
  • Chronic porphyria
  • Autosomal dominant
  • Deficiency in Uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase
  • Clinical onset is during the fourth or fifth decade of life
  • Porphyrin accumulation leads to cutaneous symptoms and urine that is red to brown in natural light and pink to red in fluorescent light
  • Clinical expression determined by many factors like hepatic iron overload, exposure to sunlight, hepatitis B or C, HIV

Option D: Protoporphyrinogen oxidase defect lead to Variegate porphyria.


Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 31 PN 310
